instruction: Provide an example of how a table of contents can be generated automatically in a LATEX document. Make sure your example contains the necessary commands.
output:
Sure, here's an example of how to generate a table of contents automatically in a LaTeX document using the `toc` package:
```
\documentclass{article}
% add other packages as needed
\usepackage{toc}
% set the title of the table of contents
\renewcommand{\contentsname}{Table of Contents}
% generate the table of contents
\listofcontents
```
This code will create a table of contents with the specified title that matches the level of the section headings in your document. You can customize the style of the table of contents by changing the settings in the `toc` package.

instruction: You should take the time to read the situation and problem carefully and give the best advice you can.
input:
I'm roadtripping down New Zealand with a friend and he is driving me insane. He hasn't enjoyed all the tours we've been on and doesn't want to chat about ANYTHING. We're a week into our trip and this is the quietest I've ever been when hanging out with another person as he rebuffs all my attempts at conversation. He wears his airpods in the car and around the accommodation - not that I've kept trying to talk to him. Honestly, he is bringing some seriously bad vibes to everything and it's ruining my trip.
We don't have anything booked in yet for the South Island, so I'm planning to ditch him in Wellington at the ferry. Probably book my own car in Picton and just relax alone for the rest of the trip. (Just thinking about it is such sharp relief that it makes me feel emotional. I'll pay whatever price I have to just to get away from him.)
Obviously telling him he is ruining my trip with his negative energy isn't the best way to approach this.
Any advice for the best approach so we can split amicably? Or at least not have an argument that ends with very hurt feelings?
output: TL;DR: Friend is being a Debbie Downer on roadtrip, I want to be rid of him. How can I split amicably?

instruction: You are given a description that provides a set of facts or a scenario. It is up to you to craft a story from these facts and scenarios. The missing pieces must be filled in with imaginative but logical information.
input: Ten European football teams – the Netherlands, England, Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and Wales – will participate in a season-long “OneLove” campaign promoting inclusion and opposing discrimination.
output:
Each club will wear a special-edition shirt and training top featuring the diversity symbol.
The Netherlands’ team will wear an all-orange strip, while England’s players will sport an all-red kit. Belgium’s men will don yellow shirts and shorts, while their women’s team will wear black and yellow. Denmark, whose men’s team will play in white, will have the rainbow colors on their shirts. France will turn out in blue shirts, while Germany’s players will wear red shirts. Norway’s men will wear green tops, while Sweden’s team, which includes both men and women, will wear yellow and green. Switzerland will have red shirts, while Wales will wear all red.

instruction: A job description is a document that clearly states the requirements, duties, responsibilities, and skills required to perform a specific role. You need to write a job description based on the given information. You should describe responsibilities and duties in your job description in a logical order. Remember that potential employees often get their first impression of your company from your job description. So, the job description should convey the attractiveness of your company.
input:
Company: [Company name]
Job: Software Engineer
Job Responsibilities:
Receive and perform code reviews with other engineers.
Write unit, integration, and end-to-end tests to verify functionality using automated testing frameworks such as Pytest.
Work collaboratively with fellow software engineers to build features requested by business stakeholders.
Participate in Agile teams to develop, test, and debug complex data processing pipelines and data analysis applications using big data processing systems such as Apache Spark.
Diagnose, debug, and perform root cause analysis of issues and defects.
Skills and experience that will lead to success:
Experience with a modern software programming language. We use Python, and Pyspark extensively.
Experience with cloud systems like AWS or Azure
Experience writing SQL queries 
Strong written and verbal communication skills
Eagerness to work in a highly-collaborative environment
Some visualization experience such as Tableau or PowerBI is helpful
output:
.
Experience with DevOps culture and practices.
Bachelors or Masters in Computer Science, Software Engineering, or related field.

instruction: Consider the best time of year to visit the given city, and provide your reasons for choosing that time.
input: Sydney, Australia
output:
is best visited during the summer months (December to February). The weather is warm and temperatures can reach up to 30 degrees Celsius, which is perfect for exploring the city and its many attractions. There are also many festivals and events held during this time, such as the Sydney Festival and the Australian Open tennis tournament.
Another great time to visit Sydney is during the autumn months (March to May). The weather is cooler but still pleasant, and there are fewer crowds than during the summer months. This is also a great time to see the changing of the leaves on the many trees throughout the city.
If you're looking for a quieter time to visit Sydney, the winter months (June to August) may be ideal. Tourist numbers are lower, meaning you'll have more of the city to yourself. It can also be a great time to enjoy some of the city's many indoor attractions, such as museums and galleries.

instruction: Provide a Java solution to the following problem.
input:
Given an integer n, return true if it is a power of three. Otherwise, return false.
An integer n is a power of three, if there exists an integer x such that n == 3^x.

Example 1:
In: n = 27
Out: true
Explanation: 27 = 3^3

Example 2:
In: n = 0
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3^x = 0.

Example 3:
In: n = -1
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3x = (-1).
 
Constraints:
-231 <= n <= 231 - 1
Follow up: Could you solve it without loops/recursion?

instruction: The given article should be checked for any scientific errors and corrected if necessary.
input: Zinc is an essential mineral that is required for good health. It is involved in many biochemical processes in the body and is necessary for the proper functioning of the immune system. Excess zink is not harmful as it is excreted in the urine.
output: The recommended daily intake of zinc is 8-11 mg per day for adults. Good sources of zinc include oysters (140 mg per serving), red meat (6-9 mg per serving), poultry (2-3 mg per serving), beans and lentils (2-5 mg per serving), nuts (1-2 mg per serving), and seeds (0.5-1 mg per serving).

instruction: Summarize the article you have been given in a brief manner.
input:
Mathematics and art are related in a variety of ways. Mathematics has itself been described as an art motivated by beauty. Mathematics can be discerned in arts such as music, dance, painting, architecture, sculpture, and textiles. This article focuses, however, on mathematics in the visual arts.
Mathematics and art have a long historical relationship. Artists have used mathematics since the 4th century BC when the Greek sculptor Polykleitos wrote his Canon, prescribing proportions conjectured to have been based on the ratio 1:√2 for the ideal male nude. Persistent popular claims have been made for the use of the golden ratio in ancient art and architecture, without reliable evidence. In the Italian Renaissance, Luca Pacioli wrote the influential treatise De divina proportione (1509), illustrated with woodcuts by Leonardo da Vinci, on the use of the golden ratio in art. Another Italian painter, Piero della Francesca, developed Euclid's ideas on perspective in treatises such as De Prospectiva Pingendi, and in his paintings. The engraver Albrecht Dürer made many references to mathematics in his work Melencolia I. In modern times, the graphic artist M. C. Escher made intensive use of tessellation and hyperbolic geometry, with the help of the mathematician H. S. M. Coxeter, while the De Stijl movement led by Theo van Doesburg and Piet Mondrian explicitly embraced geometrical forms. Mathematics has inspired textile arts such as quilting, knitting, cross-stitch, crochet, embroidery, weaving, Turkish and other carpet-making, as well as kilim. In Islamic art, symmetries are evident in forms as varied as Persian girih and Moroccan zellige tilework, Mughal jali pierced stone screens, and widespread muqarnas vaulting.

instruction: Improve the article using your knowledge of the topic in order to make it more informative.
input: The "fair trade" movement, also known as the "trade justice" movement, promotes the use of labour, environmental and social standards for the production of commodities, particularly those exported from the Third and Second Worlds to the First World. Such ideas have also sparked a debate on whether trade itself should be codified as a human right.
output:
While the movement has gained acceptance and become popular, critics argue that it ignores the actual producers of goods, and instead promotes a neo-colonialist agenda.
The fair trade movement grew out of efforts to alleviate poverty and improve conditions for farmers in developing countries. According to a 2014 report by the Fairtrade Foundation, products carrying the Fairtrade certification mark have a 25% share of the global market for certified commodities. In 2013, $6.6 billion worth of products were sold with the Fairtrade label.

instruction: Please answer the following question based on the information provided in the article.
input:
Development studies is an interdisciplinary branch of social science. Development studies is offered as a specialized master's degree in a number of reputed universities around the world. It has grown in popularity as a subject of study since the early 1990s, and has been most widely taught and researched in developing countries and countries with a colonial history, such as the UK, where the discipline originated.  Students of development studies often choose careers in international organisations such as the United Nations, World Bank, non-governmental organisations (NGOs), media and journalism houses, private sector development consultancy firms, corporate social responsibility (CSR) bodies and research centers.
What are some popular careers for students of development studies?

instruction: Provide a detailed explanation of the steps that are required in order to construct the given project.
input: Steam Engine Using an Empty Beer Can
output:
Assuming you have an empty beer can, here are the steps to build a steam engine using it:

1. Cut off the bottom of the can so that it is flat and smooth.
2. Drill two holes in the middle of the can, one near the top and one near the bottom.
3. Insert a piece of wire into each hole.
4. Connect the wires to a battery.
5. Place a drop of soap on the wire connected to the positive pole of the battery.
6. Apply heat to the wire with the soap on it.
7. The steam will escape through the hole at the top of the can.

instruction: Provide a formula for computing the nth term in the given sequence
output:
The nth term of the given sequence is given by the formula:
nth term = a + (n-1)d
where a is the first term, d is the common difference, and n is the term number.
In this case, a = 5, d = 9, and n = 6 (since we are finding the 6th term). Plugging these values into the formula, we get:
nth term = 5 + (6-1)9 = 5 + 84 = 99
Therefore, the 6th term of the given sequence is 99.

instruction: Describe the content of the article in a brief manner.
input: A study published earlier this year by Zee and her team examined the role of light in sleep for healthy adults in their 20s. Sleeping for only one night with a dim light, such as a TV set with the sound off, raised the blood sugar and heart rate of the young people during the sleep lab experiment. An elevated heart rate at night has been shown in prior studies to be a risk factor for future heart disease and early death, while higher blood sugar levels are a sign of insulin resistance, which can ultimately lead to type 2 diabetes.
output:
The researchers then repeated the experiment with a group of young people who were overweight or obese. This time the extra light made their blood sugar levels rise even higher, compared to when they slept in a dark room. And when they slept in dim light again, their heart rate was even higher than the first time around.
“This study strongly suggests that any source of artificial light during sleep might have adverse metabolic effects,” Zee said.

instruction: Choose an appealing title for your post.
input: The typical avocado is over 300 calories from the oil in it. That’s the amount of calories in a large candy bar. output: Avocados are the best thing on the planet, but they are quite calorie dense. I usually just have half of one with my lunch and dinner, and I’m fine. I think as long as you don’t go overboard, you’ll be fine.

instruction: Regex is a set of characters that define a search pattern. This kind of pattern is usually used by string-searching algorithms to find or replace strings or to validate inputs. Convert the natural english text to regex.
input: Match a valid ip address
output:
.
A valid IP address can be represented as four sets of decimal digits from 0 to 255, with a hyphen between each set (e.g., 192.168.0.1). A valid IPv4 address contains a colon at the end, and an IPv6 address contains an equal sign and two colons after the last set of digits.

instruction: Review the property description and tell us what is good and what is bad about it and list its key takeaways.
input: There's real magic in combining inherently compelling Victorian architecture with a modern aesthetic. Add in an extraordinary multi-level garden & the result is the undeniable elegance of 444 29th St. The front of the home is light-filled w/ a seamless connection between living, dining & kitchen. Newly updated kitchen w/ quartz counters & upgraded appliances. A lg dining rm has a bay of windows &, when paired w/ the adjacent living rm, provides an ideal space to entertain. 2 lg bdrms on this level are at the rear. Both w/ lg closets & walk out to the garden. Stylishly remodeled full bath on this level. 3rd bdrm/2nd full bath are located on the ground floor - perfect as a guest rm, home office, fitness area, etc. The enormous garden occupies an extra deep lot & is beautifully landscaped & terraced. Laundry/storage rm, 1-car garage pkg, Tesla solar panels. Prime, flat part of Noe Valley - short walk to all that Noe has to offer. Steps from the J-Church & convenient to shuttles/freeways.

instruction: A user story is an informal, general explanation of a software feature written from the perspective of the end user or customer. Write a user story for a given software.
input: Gmail
output:
. 1/08/2019В В· I've been writing user stories for years, but I still struggle with making them good. If you're stuck on how to write better user stories, here are 7 common mistakes to avoid. A user story is in the right format if it answers these three questions: Who? (user) What? (action) Why? (reason) For example: As a new hire at my company, I want to know who my teammates are so I can get to know them better. The user story is written as if the user were speaking directly to the development team., How to Write User Stories. In this article. Adding Detail to the Story; Example; Related Articles . Resources. Add Relevant Tags Add any tags that accurately describe the article. Popular Tags agile , scrum , user story , xp. Related Articles . Agile Methodology and Software Development.
How to Write User Stories вЂ” Smartsheet Blog
How to Write User Stories Agile Alliance. User stories are one of the most important artifacts in agile software development. They help bridge the gap between technical and business requirements by providing simple, clear descriptions of what users need from a system. Learn how to write effective user stories with examples. How do you write user stories? Many people think that writing user stories is easy because they are just brief stories from the perspective of the end-user. However, when you actually start writing user stories, you may find it difficult to write them properly., User Stories Tutorial Creating and Writing User Most of the time you will be writing user stories with other people, so make sure you understand the background of the story and why it is being written before you begin. For example, if this is your first user story you may not know the details of the other.
User Stories Tutorial Creating and Writing

input: history of the USA
output:
: native american history.
Native American History is a very interesting subject, especially when it comes to the struggle and resistance of Native Americans against the unjust laws and actions taken by the United States Government. The Trail of Tears was an example of forced relocation of Native American Tribes. Lewis & Clark Expedition was an example of how the federal government funded exploration of lands west of the Mississippi River.

instruction: Using the ingredients that are available, create a dinner recipe.
input: Kale + almond butter + apple cider vinegar + agave nectar + tamari
output:
+ garlic.
Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat and add 1 tbsp of olive oil. Add the kale and cook for about 2 minutes, until it starts to wilt. Add the almond butter and stir until well combined. Reduce the heat to low and add the apple cider vinegar, agave nectar, tamari and garlic. Simmer for about 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.

instruction: Design a simple training challenge on Strava that everyone could attend.
output: The training challenge should be something that is open to all Strava users, regardless of their experience or fitness level. The goal of the challenge should be to promote healthy habits and encourage people to stay active. The challenge should have a simple structure, with clear instructions and a set time frame. For example, the challenge could be to complete 10,000 steps per day for the next seven days. Participants would track their progress on Strava and share their progress on social media using a specific hashtag.
